journal-title-group.journal-title: Some evil scientific journal who stole the copywrite

abstract.p: My awesome science will cure this unpleasant disease and save the world somehow

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Unpleasant disease sucks, see Figure 1.
We can have supplementary figures/tables too, with their own numbering and everything, see Figure S1 & Table S1.

caption.p: Figure 1: A cool figure showing important stuff

sec.p: We can cite other stuff too, Quarto is pretty neat!(Allaire et al. 2022)
We can even embed stuff plots and tables from other notebooks, Figure 2! Notice how we get a handy link to the source notebook for the chunk too!
And here’s a table, Table 1

sec.title: 2. Results
sec.p: I already put them in the introduction, what do you want from me?! I can reference that section though Section 1, so that’s neat

sec.title: 2.1 Some particular aspect of the results
sec.p: We can have subsections too, isn’t this fun

sec.title: 3. Discussion
sec.p: And R is pretty neat too!(2024)

sec.title: 4. Supplementary materials
sec.p: And here a supplementary table

caption.p: Table S1: And here’s a table caption.
Table S2: A table with the packages used and their versions

filter, lag

intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

sec.code:
# Get session information session_info <- sessioninfo::session_info()
# Extract package information package_info <- session_info$packages %>% dplyr::select(package, loadedversion, source) %>% dplyr::arrange(package)
# Convert to a data frame package_df <- as.data.frame(package_info) # Print table package_df |> dplyr::group_by(source) |> gt::gt()
